subject: Re: [PATCH] filter stack traces in junit

messageBody:
Hey,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> I'm afraid that after discussion, we're still reluctant to have JUnit
> natively filter stack traces. It looks to me that this is something
> that could work in a custom runner--are you interested in seeing if
this
> is so?

Maybe. My time is pretty limited in the coming weeks though. One thing
to think about: maybe it'd make sense to have a filteredTrace property
on the result object (I'm not sure how this actually works, would we
need to clone exceptions).

What use cases are you thinking of for unfiltered stack traces? Are
these cases so common that a system property to toggle the filtering
wouldn't meet everyone's needs?

The fact that both ant and eclipse (the two main frontends to junit)
filter stack traces *by default* seems to be a sign that the primary
user base wants filtering. However, the filters used today actually
lose *real* data because they filter out things like sun's reflection
technology, which might be important for a test case that used reflection.

> Also, thank you for all of your feedback so far, and please do keep
> considering ways we can improve the framework. The sourceforge project
> page has a convenient place for any future patches. Thanks,

Ok, thanks. I wasn't quite sure what the best place was.

-- Ben
